EyeContact.question: When your child speaks to family members, how do they maintain eye contact?
options: A: They maintain eye contact and seem engaged.
B: They look at family members but occasionally glance away.
C: They often look at the ground or away.
D: They avoid making eye contact entirely.

EyeContact.question: How does your child respond when meeting new people?
options: A: They confidently make eye contact and smile.
B: They look at the person but seem shy.
C: They avoid eye contact and seem uncomfortable.
D: They look away and don’t acknowledge the person.

EyeContact.question: How does your child react when someone is speaking to them?
options: A: They look at the speaker and nod to show they are listening.
B: They occasionally make eye contact but look away often.
C: They don’t seem to pay much attention.
D: They look away and appear uninterested.

EyeContact.question: How does your child behave during a presentation or speech?
options: A: They maintain eye contact with the audience.
B: They make eye contact but often look at their notes.
C: They glance at the audience but mainly look down.
D: They avoid eye contact and focus on their notes.

EyeContact.question: How does your child interact with adults?
options: A: They look adults in the eye and engage confidently.
B: They are polite but avoid direct eye contact.
C: They appear shy and look down when speaking.
D: They seem uncomfortable and avoid eye contact altogether.

Behaviour.question: How does your child behave in group settings?
options: A: They actively participate and engage with others.
B: They join in but sometimes stay quiet.
C: They seem withdrawn and prefer to stay on the sidelines.
D: They act out or disrupt the group.

Behaviour.question: How does your child react when they want something?
options: A: They ask politely and wait for a response.
B: They ask but might become impatient.
C: They often whine or complain to get their way.
D: They throw a tantrum or become upset.

Behaviour.question: How does your child treat their belongings?
options: A: They take care of their things and keep them organized.
B: They manage but sometimes leave things out.
C: They often forget or misplace their belongings.
D: They are careless and do not take care of their items.

Behaviour.question: How does your child respond to rules at home?
options: A: They follow rules and respect boundaries.
B: They sometimes follow rules but need reminders.
C: They frequently challenge rules and push limits.
D: They ignore rules altogether.

Behaviour.question: How does your child show kindness to others?
options: A: They often help others and show compassion.
B: They are kind but may need encouragement.
C: They sometimes struggle to be kind.
D: They rarely show kindness or concern for others.

SocialRelationship.question: How does your child make new friends?
options: A: They approach others and introduce themselves easily.
B: They wait for others to come to them.
C: They feel shy and don’t know how to start a conversation.
D: They prefer to stay alone and don’t seek friendships.

SocialRelationship.question: How does your child maintain friendships?
options: A: They keep in touch and make plans regularly.
B: They reach out occasionally but may not follow up.
C: They have trouble staying connected.
D: They rarely interact with friends.

SocialRelationship.question: How does your child handle conflicts with friends?
options: A: They talk things out and try to resolve the issue.
B: They avoid the issue but still want to be friends.
C: They often argue and struggle to find a solution.
D: They ignore the conflict and act like nothing happened.

SocialRelationship.question: How does your child respond to invitations to play with others?
options: A: They excitedly accept and look forward to playing.
B: They agree but seem indifferent.
C: They often decline invitations.
D: They avoid social interactions and prefer to be alone.

SpeechConveyance.question: How clearly does your child express their thoughts?
options: A: They articulate their ideas clearly and confidently.
B: They express themselves but sometimes struggle with words.
C: They mumble or speak too softly.
D: They have trouble getting their point across.

SpeechConveyance.question: How does your child ask for help when needed?
options: A: They confidently ask for help when unsure.
B: They hesitate but eventually ask.
C: They avoid asking and try to figure it out alone.
D: They become frustrated and refuse to ask for help.

SpeechConveyance.question: How does your child share stories or experiences with others?
options: A: They tell stories enthusiastically and keep others engaged.
B: They share stories but lack detail.
C: They struggle to share and often get distracted.
D: They don’t share stories or experiences with others.

SpeechConveyance.question: How does your child respond when asked a question?
options: A: They answer confidently and provide explanations.
B: They answer but seem unsure.
C: They often give short or unclear answers.
D: They avoid answering or go silent.

SpeechConveyance.question: How does your child engage in conversations with peers?
options: A: They actively participate and ask questions.
B: They join in but mainly listen.
C: They rarely contribute to conversations.
D: They seem uninterested in talking.

ConcentrationLevel.question: How does your child focus on homework or school projects?
options: A: They concentrate and complete tasks efficiently.
B: They focus but need occasional breaks.
C: They struggle to concentrate and often get distracted.
D: They avoid homework and find excuses not to do it.

ConcentrationLevel.question: How does your child behave during lessons in school?
options: A: They pay attention and participate actively.
B: They listen but may zone out at times.
C: They often get distracted by their surroundings.
D: They are disruptive and do not focus.

ConcentrationLevel.question: How does your child respond when engaged in a game or activity?
options: A: They focus and enjoy the activity fully.
B: They participate but get distracted occasionally.
C: They frequently lose interest and wander off.
D: They struggle to stay engaged and leave the activity early.

ConcentrationLevel.question: How does your child handle noisy environments?
options: A: They stay focused and block out distractions.
B: They struggle but can manage with effort.
C: They get easily distracted and can’t concentrate.
D: They become overwhelmed and can’t focus at all.

ConcentrationLevel.question: How does your child react when they have multiple tasks to complete?
options: A: They manage their time well and prioritize tasks.
B: They try to juggle tasks but feel stressed.
C: They struggle to keep track and feel overwhelmed.
D: They avoid doing any tasks altogether.

SelfRegulation.question: How does your child handle frustration?
options: A: They stay calm and try to solve the problem.
B: They feel frustrated but manage to cope.
C: They often get upset and express their anger.
D: They lose control and throw a tantrum.

SelfRegulation.question: How does your child respond to disappointing news?
options: A: They accept it and look for alternatives.
B: They feel sad but eventually move on.
C: They dwell on it and become upset.
D: They refuse to accept it and act out.

SelfRegulation.question: How does your child react when they need to wait for something?
options: A: They patiently wait without complaint.
B: They fidget or ask how much longer.
C: They express anger and frustration.
D: They get upset and refuse to wait.

SelfRegulation.question: How does your child behave when they have to follow rules?
options: A: They understand and follow rules without issue.
B: They sometimes question the rules but generally follow them.
C: They resist rules and challenge authority.
D: They ignore rules and do what they want.

SelfRegulation.question: How does your child respond to peer pressure?
options: A: They confidently stand their ground and say no.
B: They hesitate but usually make the right choice.
C: They feel pressured and often go along with friends.
D: They give in and do things they shouldn’t.

StressLevel.question: How does your child handle stressful situations, like exams?
options: A: They stay calm and prepare well.
B: They feel a little anxious but manage it.
C: They become very stressed and have trouble focusing.
D: They panic and struggle to cope.

StressLevel.question: How does your child react to changes in routine?
options: A: They adapt quickly and adjust their plans.
B: They take a little time to adjust but manage.
C: They feel anxious and resist the changes.
D: They become upset and refuse to change.

StressLevel.question: How does your child respond when faced with multiple tasks?
options: A: They prioritize and handle tasks well.
B: They feel overwhelmed but try to manage.
C: They struggle to keep up and feel stressed.
D: They freeze and don’t know where to start.

StressLevel.question: How does your child behave when there’s a lot of noise around?
options: A: They can focus despite the noise.
B: They find it a bit distracting but cope.
C: They become annoyed and can’t concentrate.
D: They feel overwhelmed and leave the area.

StressLevel.question: How does your child cope with disappointment?
options: A: They accept it and move forward positively.
B: They feel sad but bounce back.
C: They dwell on the disappointment and become upset.
D: They react angrily and refuse to accept it.

BodyMind.question: How does your child perform physical activities or sports?
options: A: They excel and participate with enthusiasm.
B: They try their best but may struggle.
C: They avoid physical activities and prefer sitting out.
D: They have difficulty coordinating movements.

BodyMind.question: How does your child react when trying new physical skills?
options: A: They are excited and eager to learn.
B: They feel nervous but give it a try.
C: They hesitate and might refuse to try.
D: They become frustrated and give up easily.

BodyMind.question: How does your child behave during dance or movement activities?
options: A: They join in and move confidently.
B: They participate but seem shy.
C: They are unsure and move hesitantly.
D: They avoid movement activities altogether.

BodyMind.question: How does your child coordinate their movements while playing?
options: A: They move fluidly and enjoy playing games.
B: They are somewhat coordinated but stumble occasionally.
C: They often trip or bump into things.
D: They have trouble controlling their movements.

Empathy.question: How does your child respond when they see someone sad?
options: A: They ask if the person is okay and offer comfort.
B: They notice but don’t know how to help.
C: They ignore it and move on.
D: They laugh or make jokes, not understanding the situation.

Empathy.question: How does your child react when they hear about someone else's problems?
options: A: They express concern and ask questions.
B: They listen but don’t say much.
C: They seem uninterested and change the topic.
D: They dismiss the issue and say it’s not a big deal.

Empathy.question: How does your child comfort a friend who is upset?
options: A: They offer a hug and listen to their feelings.
B: They try to cheer them up with jokes.
C: They feel uncomfortable and don’t know what to do.
D: They ignore their friend and do something else.

Empathy.question: How does your child respond to stories or movies with sad endings?
options: A: They express sadness and talk about their feelings.
B: They feel a bit sad but move on quickly.
C: They don’t seem affected by the ending.
D: They laugh or make light of the situation.

Empathy.question: How does your child show care for pets or animals?
options: A: They take time to play with and care for them.
B: They occasionally check in on their pets.
C: They seem indifferent and rarely interact.
D: They are rough or careless with animals.

Motivation.question: How does your child react when faced with a challenging task?
options: A: They tackle it with enthusiasm and determination.
B: They feel nervous but try their best.
C: They hesitate and need encouragement.
D: They give up quickly when things get tough.

Motivation.question: How does your child approach goals or projects?
options: A: They set goals and work hard to achieve them.
B: They have some goals but struggle to follow through.
C: They seem unmotivated and lack direction.
D: They don’t set goals and avoid challenges.

Motivation.question: How does your child respond to praise or rewards?
options: A: They feel proud and motivated to do more.
B: They appreciate it but don’t seek it out.
C: They seem indifferent to praise or rewards.
D: They become overly reliant on praise to feel good.

Motivation.question: How does your child handle setbacks or failures?
options: A: They learn from it and try again.
B: They feel disappointed but eventually move on.
C: They dwell on the failure and feel discouraged.
D: They give up entirely and refuse to try again.

Motivation.question: How does your child respond to learning new skills?
options: A: They are excited and eager to learn.
B: They feel nervous but want to try.
C: They seem reluctant and avoid new challenges.
D: They don’t care to learn new things.

Mindfulness.question: How does your child react during quiet or reflection time?
options: A: They embrace the quiet and use the time to relax.
B: They feel a bit restless but manage.
C: They struggle to sit still and focus.
D: They dislike quiet time and find it boring.

Mindfulness.question: How does your child handle distractions while studying?
options: A: They stay focused and manage distractions well.
B: They sometimes get distracted but refocus quickly.
C: They easily lose focus and struggle to get back on track.
D: They give in to distractions and can’t concentrate.

Mindfulness.question: How does your child practice being present in the moment?
options: A: They can enjoy activities without distraction.
B: They sometimes get lost in their thoughts.
C: They often daydream and lose track of the activity.
D: They have difficulty engaging with the present.

Mindfulness.question: How does your child respond when they feel overwhelmed?
options: A: They take a moment to breathe and gather themselves.
B: They feel overwhelmed but try to cope.
C: They panic and struggle to calm down.
D: They become frantic and can’t regain control.

Mindfulness.question: How does your child engage in activities that require patience?
options: A: They are patient and enjoy the process.
B: They sometimes fidget but keep trying.
C: They quickly lose interest and give up.
D: They become frustrated and act out.

SelfAwareness.question: How does your child express their feelings?
options: A: They can name their emotions and talk about them.
B: They sometimes express how they feel.
C: They struggle to identify their feelings.
D: They often deny their feelings and avoid talking about them.

SelfAwareness.question: How does your child react to feedback about their behavior?
options: A: They listen and reflect on it thoughtfully.
B: They consider it but may get defensive.
C: They ignore feedback and continue as usual.
D: They become upset and argue against it.

SelfAwareness.question: How does your child understand their strengths and weaknesses?
options: A: They can articulate what they do well and where they struggle.
B: They recognize some strengths but overlook weaknesses.
C: They have a hard time identifying either.
D: They refuse to acknowledge their weaknesses.

SelfAwareness.question: How does your child respond when they make a mistake?
options: A: They admit it and learn from it.
B: They might blame others but feel guilty.
C: They deny it and refuse to acknowledge the mistake.
D: They become upset and withdraw.

SelfAwareness.question: How does your child reflect on their day?
options: A: They think about what went well and what didn’t.
B: They consider some things but don’t go into detail.
C: They don’t think about their day much.
D: They focus only on the negative aspects.

Creativity.question: How does your child approach creative tasks, like art or storytelling?
options: A: They dive in and enjoy expressing their ideas.
B: They feel inspired but might hold back.
C: They struggle to come up with ideas.
D: They avoid creative tasks altogether.

Creativity.question: How does your child respond to new experiences or challenges?
options: A: They are excited to try new things.
B: They feel hesitant but want to explore.
C: They are resistant to change and prefer the familiar.
D: They actively avoid new experiences.

Creativity.question: How does your child use their imagination during play?
options: A: They create elaborate stories and scenarios.
B: They have some imaginative play but stick to familiar ideas.
C: They engage in play but lack imagination.
D: They don’t engage in imaginative play.

Creativity.question: How does your child handle constructive criticism on their creative work?
options: A: They appreciate it and use it to improve.
B: They consider it but may feel defensive.
C: They struggle to accept criticism and ignore it.
D: They become upset and refuse to discuss it.

Creativity.question: How does your child solve problems or puzzles?
options: A: They think creatively and come up with innovative solutions.
B: They rely on tried-and-true methods but can adapt.
C: They struggle and feel frustrated by challenges.
D: They give up quickly when faced with a puzzle.

TimeManagement.question: How does your child handle completing tasks on time?
options: A: They manage their time well and meet deadlines.
B: They sometimes struggle but usually complete tasks.
C: They often run late and need reminders.
D: They consistently miss deadlines and give up.

TimeManagement.question: How does your child prioritize their activities?
options: A: They know what is important and focus on it first.
B: They try to prioritize but get sidetracked.
C: They have difficulty prioritizing and often feel overwhelmed.
D: They don’t prioritize and act on impulse.

TimeManagement.question: How does your child plan their day or week?
options: A: They make a schedule and stick to it.
B: They plan sometimes but often forget.
C: They rarely plan and go with the flow.
D: They don’t plan at all and act randomly.

TimeManagement.question: How does your child handle distractions when working on a task?
options: A: They stay focused and avoid distractions.
B: They sometimes get distracted but refocus.
C: They easily lose focus and struggle to return to the task.
D: They give in to distractions and lose track of time.

TimeManagement.question: How does your child respond to a busy schedule?
options: A: They handle it well and manage their time effectively.
B: They feel a little overwhelmed but cope.
C: They become stressed and have trouble keeping up.
D: They give up and refuse to manage their schedule.

Optimism.question: How does your child react when they face a setback or challenge?
options: A: They believe things will get better and keep trying.
B: They feel disappointed but think they can improve next time.
C: They become discouraged and doubt their abilities.
D: They believe they will always fail.

Optimism.question: When your child thinks about their future, how do they feel?
options: A: They are excited and look forward to new possibilities.
B: They feel hopeful but have some concerns.
C: They worry about what might go wrong.
D: They don’t see a bright future ahead.

Optimism.question: How does your child respond when others express negative opinions or doubts?
options: A: They remain positive and try to encourage others.
B: They consider the opinions but still feel hopeful.
C: They start to believe the negative thoughts themselves.
D: They feel defeated by the negativity.

Optimism.question: When your child thinks about their accomplishments, how do they view them?
options: A: They feel proud and believe they can achieve more.
B: They appreciate their successes but feel there’s more to do.
C: They often downplay their achievements.
D: They feel like they never do well enough.

Optimism.question: How does your child approach new experiences or challenges?
options: A: They look forward to the opportunity to learn something new.
B: They feel a bit anxious but want to try anyway.
C: They hesitate and prefer to stick with what they know.
D: They avoid new experiences out of fear of failure.
